images.altText: Stylized image of beakers, flasks, test tubes, and the periodic table

pageData.text: In this investigation, students will use basic scientific measuring equipment to determine the <button class='glossary-text'>accuracy</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>uncertainty</button> associated with measurements using common laboratory glassware.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: No other materials are required at this time.

pageData.altText:
Preparation – 5 minutes 
Activity 1: Determination of Uncertainty in Lab Balance – 20 minutes 
Activity 2: Determination of Uncertainty in Common Glassware – 60 minutes 
Activity 3: Determination of Accuracy in Common Glassware – 40 minutes
pageData.title: Time Requirements
Outcomes
text: Determine the <button class='glossary-text'>uncertainty</button> of measurements with <button class='glossary-text'>standard</button> glassware and equipment.
Determine the <button class='glossary-text'>accuracy</button> of measurements with standard glassware.

pageData.subTitle: Personal protective equipment (PPE)

pageData.text: Communication is paramount in the scientific community because reproducibility is what establishes the theories and laws we recognize within the various scientific disciplines. If presented theories cannot be reproduced by scientists across the globe, they will not be confirmed. And scientists cannot reproduce an experiment if the conditions, procedures, and results are not clearly communicated via terminology every scientist understands. The General Conference on Weights and Measures began creating a common language among scientists when they defined the International System of Units, abbreviated SI (from the French Le Systeme International d’Unites). You can consider the SI system as the modern form of the metric system. The SI system is the only system of measurement that is officially recognized in nearly every country in the world. When reporting measurements, <button class='glossary-text'>significant figures</button> complement the SI units by allowing scientists to recognize how precise a reported answer is, or how much <button class='glossary-text'>uncertainty</button> there is within reported results. This also allows scientists to immediately gauge whether their equipment is capable of accurately reproducing the reported values of an experiment.

pageData.desc: Five scientists in lab coats posing as if in the middle of a discussion in a laboratory setting.
pageData.altText: Five scientists in lab coats posing as if in the middle of a discussion in a laboratory setting.

pageData.text: Measurements can come in many forms—such as length, weight (mass), volume, and temperature—but there are many other forms you may encounter in the future. This investigation will focus on two: how to measure weight and volume, and some common equipment used to measure both.

pageData.subTitle: Using Your Balance
pageData.text: To measure the weight of an object (more scientifically referred to as the mass), a balance or scale is used. Figure 1 shows a small balance that was used to weigh all substances in this investigation. This balance has complete instructions on its use on the inside of its lid. When looking at the top of the balance, there are five points of interest. First, is the pan; this is the large, flat surface above the LCD screen. Objects you wish to weigh are placed on the pan. Below the pan is the LCD screen. This is where the mass of an object on the pan is displayed. Below the screen are three buttons reading, from left to right, ON/ OFF, MODE, and TARE. When you first turn on the balance by pressing the ON/OFF button, the screen should read “0.00g“ (g stands for grams in this instance).This indicates there is no mass on the balance. If the letter at the end is not g, you would press the MODE button until “g” is listed as the units. If the screen is not indicating a mass of 0.00, pressing the TARE button will re-zero the scale.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Scale displaying a reading of 0.00 grams and the lid showing the instructions
pageData.desc: Figure 1: Scale displaying a reading of 0.00 grams and the lid showing the instructions

pageData.text: The scale should reset to 0.00 g. The scale has a maximum capacity of 100 g; if a mass greater than 100 g is placed on the pan, the screen will read “0_Ld,” indicating too large a mass has been placed on the pan.  Although you are not using an actual balance with this dry lab, you will see images of the electronic balance. When you get your kit, the balance you will receive will be exactly like the images in the dry lab manual. You will use the same set of steps shown here to measure masses using the balance.

pageData.subTitle: Measuring Liquids
pageData.text: To measure a volume of liquid, typically a piece of glassware, such as a beaker or graduated cylinder, is used. The equipment is placed on a flat countertop or table, and liquid is poured into it. The bottom of the meniscus (the concave layer of water at the top) is where the volume is measured against the scale (Figure 2). As you will see in Activity 2, the volume you read from a particular piece of glassware may be at best an estimate.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: diagram showing a close up of reading a meniscus
pageData.desc: Figure 2: diagram showing a close up of reading a meniscus

pageData.text: Having measurable results is an integral part of the scientific method. Scientists must contend with two main factors while taking measurements: the of the measurement and the of the measurement. Accuracy is how close a set of data is to the actual value. Accuracy is gauged by comparing the measured value of a known to its true value.” Ignore color of text.Precision refers to how close a data point is to other measurements in a data set.

A data set that is accurate is not necessarily precise, whereas a very precise data set could be highly inaccurate. Forces that affect the accuracy and precision in measurements are <button class='glossary-text'>error</button>. In scientific settings, error is defined as the difference between the measured value and the actual value, where the actual value is a known value, sometimes referred to as a standard. Two main types of error exist: <button class='glossary-text'>systematic error</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>random error</button>.

Systematic error causes measurements to be inaccurate by a certain value in a particular direction. Systematic error can be further divided into absolute and <button class='glossary-text'>relative error</button>. <button class='glossary-text'>Absolute error</button> has both magnitude and direction and is represented as a discrete value. For example, if your alarm clock is slow by five minutes, it has a systematic, absolute error. Each morning, you will be getting up five minutes later than planned and dealing with the potential repercussions. Absolute error can be calculated as follows:

= |measurement - actual value|
absolute = |6:35 - 6:40| = 5 minutes
The || brackets indicate that you take the absolute value of a calculation. An absolute value means the value in the bracket will always be positive.

There is a second type of <button class='glossary-text'>systematic error</button> called <button class='glossary-text'>relative error </button>, or <button class='glossary-text'>percent error</button>, which is expressed as a percentage. One of the more common measuring devices with built-in percent error is the speedometer of a car. Most automobile manufacturers have a tolerance of ±2% in their speedometers. This means that any given speedometer could read between 2% too slow or 2% too fast. If your speedometer reads 61 mph while actually traveling 60 mph, the percent error is calculated using the equation below.
relative error = |measurement - actual value|/actual value x 100%
relative error = |61 mph - 60 mph|/60 mph x 100% = 1.6%

Related to relative error is the concept of percent error. Percent error is calculated by comparing a measurement against an accepted value. Typically an accepted value is measured with a high level of and , but it is still a measured value—no matter what, there is always some form of associated with a measured value.
percent error = |measurement - accepted value|/accepted value x 100%

pageData.question: Most automobile manufacturers have a tolerance of ±2% in their speedometers. Which of the following best describes the meaning of this tolerance?

options.text: The car’s actual speed could be 2 percent faster than the speedometer’s displayed speed.
The car’s actual speed could be 20 times faster than the speedometer’s displayed speed.
The car’s actual speed could be 2 times slower than the speedometer’s displayed speed.
The car’s actual speed could be 2 mph slower than the speedometer's displayed speed.
The car’s actual speed could be 20 mph faster than the speedometer’s displayed speed.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A tolerance of ±2% means that any given speedometer could read between 2% too slow or 2% too fast.

pageData.question: A scale at the gym displays your weight as 149 lbs when your actual weight is 150 lbs. What type of error is this?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The scale at the gym being off by 1 lb is an example of absolute error.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
Systematic error is a type of error that causes measurements to be inaccurate by a certain value in a particular direction. Systematic error can be further divided into absolute and relative error. Absolute error has both magnitude and direction and is represented as a discrete value. For example, if your alarm clock is slow by five minutes it has a systematic, absolute error. Each morning you will be getting up five minutes later than planned and dealing with the potential repercussions. Relative error, or percent error, is expressed as a percentage. One of the more common measuring devices with built-in percent error is the speedometer of a car. Most automobile manufacturers have a tolerance of ±2% in their speedometers. This means that any given speedometer could read between 2% too slow or 2% too fast. relative error = |measurement - actual value|/actual value x 100%
relative error = |61 mph - 60 mph|/60 mph x 100% = 1.6%

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
Systematic error is a type of error that causes measurements to be inaccurate by a certain value in a particular direction. Systematic error can be further divided into absolute and relative error. Absolute error has both magnitude and direction and is represented as a discrete value. For example, if your alarm clock is slow by five minutes it has a systematic, absolute error. Each morning you will be getting up five minutes later than planned and dealing with the potential repercussions. Relative error, or percent error, is expressed as a percentage. One of the more common measuring devices with built-in percent error is the speedometer of a car. Most automobile manufacturers have a tolerance of ±2% in their speedometers. This means that any given speedometer could read between 2% too slow or 2% too fast. relative error = |measurement - actual value|/actual value x 100%
relative error = |61 mph - 60 mph|/60 mph x 100% = 1.6%

pageData.text: An important characteristic of <button class='glossary-text'>systematic error</button>, both absolute and relative, is that it can be either corrected or accounted for in future measurements since it has both direction and magnitude. With your alarm clock, you could change the time so that it is no longer 5 minutes fast; with the speedometer, you could mathematically correct for the <button class='glossary-text'>relative error</button> in future readings.

Although systematic <button class='glossary-text'>error</button> can be corrected for if discovered, <button class='glossary-text'>random error</button> will be present in all measurements. Through improved experimental design and best lab practices, random error can be reduced but can never be eliminated. The most common form of random error in a lab setting comes from the equipment. This type of random error is most commonly referred to as <button class='glossary-text'>uncertainty</button>. Uncertainty is the limit of quantifiable measurement with confidence using measuring equipment.

One method for determining the uncertainty of an analog measuring device is to utilize the scale provided on the equipment. For example, on a 10-mL graduated cylinder, there are graduations (lines) every 0.1 mL. In , the bottom of the meniscus is between the graduations of 6.7 and 6.8. Most people would read the volume as 6.75 mL. You can say with certainty that the water is between 6.70 and 6.80 mL, but many people would have difficulty determining a finer range of certainty.
A simple method for determining the measured value and the uncertainty is as follows:

measured value = high interval + low interval/2
6.75 = 6.80 + 6.70/2
uncertainty = high interval - low interval/2
0.05 = 6.80 - 6.70/2
The measured value in this example would be 6.75 mL ± 0.05 mL. The ±0.05 mL indicates confidence that the actual value for this measurement is between 6.80 mL and 6.70 mL.

With a digital device, such as a balance, <button class='glossary-text'>uncertainty</button> is generally limited to the last significant figure. For example, a balance that can read to tenths of a gram would have an uncertainty in the tenths place, typically of ±0.1 or ±0.2 grams. Uncertainty is generally calculated using a <button class='glossary-text'>standard</button> and a high number of measurements. A standard is a chemical or piece of equipment that has a known quantity associated with it, in this case a mass. For this activity, plastic cups are used as your standard for determining the uncertainty in your balance.

<button class='glossary-text'>Error</button>, uncertainty, and equipment segue into the mathematical concept of <button class='glossary-text'>significant figures</button>. Significant figures are digits relating to the <button class='glossary-text'>precision</button> of measurement. There are some general rules for determining if a digit is significant:

text: All nonzero digits are considered significant.
Zeros appearing anywhere between two nonzero digits are significant (0.1003 has four significant figures).
Leading zeros are not significant (0.0076 has two significant figures).
Trailing zeros in a number containing a decimal point are significant. For example, 35.000 has five significant figures.

pageData.text: Uncertainty limits the precision and the number of significant figures in a measurement. In the example discussed, the 6.75 mL of water in the graduated cylinder has three significant figures. The “6“ before the decimal and the “7“ and “5“ after the decimal are all considered significant. This is confirmed with the uncertainty of 0.05 mL. In this instance, the uncertainty indicates that there are no additional significant figures beyond the hundredths place. However, if the graduated cylinder was measured at 6.75 but the uncertainty was determined to be 0.20 mL, the number of significant figures would be limited to two and the measurement would be reported as 6.8 mL ± 0.2 mL.

In the next example, let’s assume that the volume measurement above had a of 1%.
6.75 mL x 1%/100% = 0.0675 mL

This would equate to an <button class='glossary-text'>absolute error</button> of 0.0675 mL in the measurement. Like 6.75 mL, 0.0675 mL has three <button class='glossary-text'>significant figures</button>. However, the process of multiplication and division has added a false <button class='glossary-text'>precision</button> to the result. The measurement 6.75 mL ± 0.0675 mL is incorrect because the calculated <button class='glossary-text'>error</button> has additional precision that the original measurement can contain. In this instance, the proper measured value would be written as 6.75 mL ± 0.07 mL. In general, you cannot gain significant figures and you cannot gain precision in a measurement through mathematical functions.

pageData.question: What is one way to reduce uncertainty when using analog measuring equipment?

options.text: Use the scale provided on the equipment.
Guess at whatever number you want.
If only two numbers are reported on a scale, estimate what the next three numbers would be.
There is no way to reduce uncertainty.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: If the bottom of the meniscus is between the graduations of 6.7 and 6.8. Most people would read the volume as 6.75 mL. You can say with certainty, based on the scale, that the water is between 6.70 and 6.80 mL, but many people would have difficulty determining a finer range of certainty.

pageData.question: A balance that can read to what degree typically has an uncertainty of ±0.1 or ±0.2 grams?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A balance that can read to tenths of a gram would have an uncertainty in the tenth’s place, typically of ±0.1 or ±0.2 grams.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Although systematic error can be corrected for if discovered, random error will be present in all measurements. Through improved experimental design and best lab practices, random error can be reduced but it can never be eliminated. The most common form of random error in a lab setting comes from the equipment. This type of random error is most commonly referred to as uncertainty. Uncertainty is the limit of quantifiable measurement with confidence using measuring equipment. One method for determining the uncertainty of an analog measuring device is to utilize the scale provided on the equipment. For example, on the 10-mL graduated cylinder below, there are graduations (lines) every 0.1 mL. With a digital device, such as the balance supplied in your equipment kit, uncertainty is generally limited to the last significant figure.

pageData.desc: This map describes the workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1, you will take the mass of two different plastic cups; you will take five readings per cup. Then, you will determine the average mass of each cup, the deviation from the average for each trial, and the deviation from the average for each cup. In Activity 2, you will take volume measurements using four different glassware items. For each item, you will measure its mass, add a target volume of water to the item, record the highest and lowest volume intervals, calculate uncertainty, and measure the mass of the item with its water. Once all the glassware items have been tested, you will calculate the mass of the water within each item. In Activity 3, you will use the current room temperature to calculate the volumes of water from Activity 2. Finally, you will compare the measured volumes against the calculated volumes.
pageData.altText: This map describes the workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1, you will take the mass of two different plastic cups; you will take five readings per cup. Then, you will determine the average mass of each cup, the deviation from the average for each trial, and the deviation from the average for each cup. In Activity 2, you will take volume measurements using four different glassware items. For each item, you will measure its mass, add a target volume of water to the item, record the highest and lowest volume intervals, calculate uncertainty, and measure the mass of the item with its water. Once all the glassware items have been tested, you will calculate the mass of the water within each item. In Activity 3, you will use the current room temperature to calculate the volumes of water from Activity 2. Finally, you will compare the measured volumes against the calculated volumes.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes an object of known mass that can be used to establish uncertainty in measurements made with a balance?
The mass of a wooden block is reported to be 5.20 g ± 0.05 g. What does the “0.05 g” indicate about the measurement?

Charlie is a chemistry student conducting an experiment at home, as approved by his professor. Despite attempts to eliminate sources of experimental error from his design, Charlie still finds his results have measurable uncertainty. Which of the following statements from Charlie’s professor best explains the results?

options.text: There is no way to eliminate all uncertainty.
The only way to eliminate all uncertainty is to use the best equipment possible.
Uncertainty can be eliminated if you have a lab partner replicate the results.
Uncertainty can be eliminated if all the equipment is properly cleaned.
The only way to eliminate uncertainty is to perform experiments in a formal lab setting.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following statements about significant figures is incorrect?

options.text: They are digits that describe the accuracy of measurement.
Trailing zeroes in a number containing a decimal point are significant.
All non-zero digits are considered significant.
The number of significant figures in a measurement is limited by uncertainty.

assestmentData.question: How many significant figures are in the number 9641.25?
How many significant figures are in the number 0.08546000?
Which of the following refers to how close data are to their actual values?
An object known to be 20 mm in length is measured as 18 mm in length. What is the percent error?

Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely.
In Activity 1, you will determine the <button class='glossary-text'>uncertainty</button> in an electronic balance by analyzing data about the mass of two different plastic cups.

pages.pageTitle:
A
 Determination of Uncertainty in Lab Balance (11 steps)
pages.title:
A
 Determination of Uncertainty in Lab Balance (11 steps)

pageData.text: Assume your balance is turned on, and the reading is stabilized at 0.00 (see Figure 3).
Two cups are labeled “#1” and “#2” (see Figure 4).

image.desc: Figure 3: Scale displaying a reading of 0.00 grams
image.altText: Figure 3: Scale displaying a reading of 0.00 grams

Figure 4: Two empty transparent plastic cups labeled '1' and '2'

pageData.text: Assume Cup #1 is placed on the balance. The mass is shown in Figure 5. Record this in Data Table 1 below “Mass of Cup #1” as Trial 1.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: Cup 1 on a weighing scale showing a reading of 10.52 grams
pageData.desc: Figure 5: Cup 1 on a weighing scale showing a reading of 10.52 grams

pageData.text: Assume Cup #1 is removed from the balance, and the balance is restabilized at 0.00.
Repeat Steps 3 and 4 for four additional trials, recording the readings shown in Figures 6–9 in Data Table 1 as Trials 2–5.

image.desc: Figure 8: Cup 1 on a weighing scale showing a reading of 10.53 grams

image.desc: Figure 9: Cup 1 on a weighing scale showing a reading of 10.54 grams

pageData.text: Assume Cup #1 has been removed, the balance as been restabilized at 0.00, and Cup #2 is on the balance. The mass is shown in Figure 10. Record this in Data Table 1 below “Mass of Cup #2” as Trial 1.

pageData.altText: Figure 10: Cup 2 on a weighing scale showing a reading of 10.45 grams
pageData.desc: Figure 10: Cup 2 on a weighing scale showing a reading of 10.45 grams

pageData.text: Assume Cup #2 is removed from the balance, and the balance is restabilized at 0.00.
Repeat Steps 6 and 7 for four additional trials, recording the readings shown in Figures 11–14 in Data Table 1 as Trials 2–5.
Determine the average mass of each cup, and record the value in Data Table 1.
For each trial, perform the following calculation:
deviation from average = |average mass of cup - mass of cup in trial|
Determine the average “deviation from average” for each cup. This is the <button class='glossary-text'>uncertainty</button> of your measurement with the balance.

pageData.text: In Activity 2, you will determine the <button class='glossary-text'>uncertainty</button> of four different pieces of glassware by analyzing data after each piece is used to measure a target volume of water.

pages.title:
B
 Determination of Uncertainty in Common Glasswar (9 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
B
 Determination of Uncertainty in Common Glassware (9 steps)

pageData.text: Assume your balance is turned on, and the reading is stabilized at 0.00 (see Figure 15).
Assume the 10-mL graduated cylinder is placed on the balance. The mass is shown in Figure 16. Record this in Data Table 2.

pageData.altText: Figure 15: Scale displaying a reading of 0.00 grams
pageData.desc: Figure 15: Scale displaying a reading of 0.00 grams

pageData.altText: Figure 16: A 10-milliliter graduated cylinder on a weighing scale showing a reading of 10.64 grams
pageData.desc: Figure 16: A 10-milliliter graduated cylinder on a weighing scale showing a reading of 10.64 grams

pageData.text: Assume the graduated cylinder has been removed from the balance and approximately 7 mL of water has been added to it (see ).
Record the volume of water in Data Table 2 based on the meniscus of the water as shown in Figure 17. Realize that, for some pieces of glassware, this may be an estimate.

pageData.altText: Figure 17: A 10-milliliter graduated cylinder showing a blue water level of 7 milliliters
pageData.desc: Figure 17: A 10-milliliter graduated cylinder showing a blue water level of 7 milliliters

pageData.text: Record the high and low volume intervals in Data Table 2. These should be volumes that you are certain the actual volume is between. Use the graduations (lines) on the glassware to help determine the high and low intervals.
Calculate the of your measurement, and record it in Data Table 2.
Uncertainty = (high volume interval - low volume interval)/2
Assume the balance reading is zeroed. The mass of the 10-mL graduated cylinder with water is shown in Figure 18. Record the mass in Data Table 2.

pageData.altText: Figure 18: A 10-milliliter graduated cylinder with 7 milliliters of blue water on a weighing scale showing a reading of 17.40 grams
pageData.desc: Figure 18: A 10-milliliter graduated cylinder with 7 milliliters of blue water on a weighing scale showing a reading of 17.40 grams

pageData.text: Repeat Steps 1–7 with each remaining glassware shown in Figures 19–24. Replace the volumes in Step 3 with the target volumes listed in Table 1. Be sure to record the data in Data Table 2.

pageData.text: Calculate the mass of water in each piece of glassware, and record the mass in Data Table 2 and 3.
Mass of water = Mass of glassware with water – Mass of empty glassware
In Activity 3, you will calculate the actual volumes of water from Activity 2 and compare these values to the experimental values to determine the of each piece of glassware.

pages.title:
C
 Determination of Accuracy in Common Glassware (3 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
C
 Determination of Accuracy in Common Glassware (3 steps)

pageData.text: Using the thermometer shown in Figure 25, record the room temperature in degrees centigrade in Data Table 3 as the current water temperature. (For simplicity, assume that the water used in Activity 2 was at this room temperature.)

pageData.altText: Figure 25: Glass thermometer showing a room temperature reading in degrees celsius
pageData.desc: Figure 25: Glass thermometer showing a room temperature reading in degrees celsius

pageData.text: Using Table 2, record the density of water at the current room temperature in Data Table 3.

tableData.text: How to use this table: If the water temperature is 23.4 °C: Start at the 23 °C row and go over to the “g/mL + 0.4 °C” column. The density at 23.4 °C would be 0.9974 g/mL.
tableData.hoverText: How to use this table: If the water temperature is 23.4 °C: Start at the 23 °C row and go over to the “g/mL + 0.4 °C” column. The density at 23.4 °C would be 0.9974 g/mL.

pageData.text: Calculate the volume of water from Activity 2 for each piece of glassware, and record it in Data Table 3.
Reminder: volume = mass/density
You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

pageData.title: Data Table 1: Determination of Uncertainty in Lab Balance

text: Suppose you continued Activity 1 using a third plastic cup of the same type. Would you expect the average deviation from the average mass to be the same or different? Explain your answer.

pageData.title: Data Table 2: Determination of Uncertainty in Common Glassware

text: Which piece of glassware has the highest degree of precision? Why?

pageData.title: Data Table 3: Determination of Accuracy in Common Glassware

tableData.text: Density of water at room temperature

text: Accuracy is gauged by comparing the measured value of a known standard to its true value. Assuming the mass of the water represents a standard for the true volume of water, which piece of glassware has the highest degree of accuracy? Why?
When measuring liquids, you should make a reading at the bottom of the meniscus. Why?

pageData.altText: Periodic Table of the Elements
pageData.content: Periodic Table of the Elements

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Scale displaying a reading of 0.00 grams and the lid showing the instructions
pageData.content: Figure 1. An electronic balance

pageData.altText: Figure 2: diagram showing a close up of reading a meniscus
pageData.content: Figure 2. Measuring from the meniscus of a liquid
Experimental Design Diagram
pageData.altText: This map describes the workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1, you will take the mass of two different plastic cups; you will take five readings per cup. Then, you will determine the average mass of each cup, the deviation from the average for each trial, and the deviation from the average for each cup. In Activity 2, you will take volume measurements using four different glassware items. For each item, you will measure its mass, add a target volume of water to the item, record the highest and lowest volume intervals, calculate uncertainty, and measure the mass of the item with its water. Once all the glassware items have been tested, you will calculate the mass of the water within each item. In Activity 3, you will use the current room temperature to calculate the volumes of water from Activity 2. Finally, you will compare the measured volumes against the calculated volumes.

data.title: Absolute error
data.content: Has both magnitude and direction and is represented as a discrete value

data.title: Accuracy
data.content: Is gauged by comparing the measured value of a known standard to its true value

data.title: Error
data.content: The difference between the measured value and the actual value, where the actual value is a known value, sometimes referred to as a standard

data.title: Percent error
data.content: A type of systematic error calculated by comparing a measurement against an accepted value

data.title: Precision
data.content: Refers to how close a data point is to other measurements in a data set

data.title: Random error
data.content: Will be present in all measurements

data.title: Relative error
data.content: a type of systematic error usually expressed as a percentage

data.title: Significant figures
data.content: Digits relating to the precision of measurement

data.title: Standard
data.content: A chemical or piece of equipment associated with a known quantity, such as mass

data.title: Systematic error
data.content: A type of error that causes measurements to be inaccurate by a certain value in a particular direction

data.title: Uncertainty
data.content: The limit of quantifiable measurement with confidence using measuring equipment
